Okay, this is real. I'm in the thick of it. Iâ€™m essentially acting as the CMO for the relaunch of **Digg** (dig.com), and while Iâ€™m surrounded by incredible assetsâ€”Digg Nation's 30K viewers, a Twitter following of 1.2 million, a killer nostalgia hook, and big-name board membersâ€”Iâ€™m also spinning in the overwhelm. Iâ€™ve got content going out daily, an all-star PR team, and a deeply loyal early audience. But thatâ€™s not enough.

Right now, the primary marketing engine is the podcast, **Digg Nation**â€”but the connection between it and the Digg brand is still abstract. Itâ€™s running, itâ€™s got traction, but it hasnâ€™t fused with the product narrative yet because the product hasnâ€™t launched. Once we launch, the show and the site will be tethered. Thatâ€™s when we start threading our stories.

Weâ€™re running a nostalgia campaignâ€”featuring legends like the crew from Tiki Bar TVâ€”and itâ€™s working. It's waking up the old guard. But nostalgia can only be the spark, not the fuel. I need more than eyesâ€”I need **engaged believers**. I need a community that goes beyond retro feelings and actually *wants what weâ€™re building*.

Weâ€™ve got huge chess pieces to play with. Alexis Ohanian. Kevin Rose. Christian Selig (Apollo dev). Jamie from WallStreetBets. These are not minor playersâ€”they're *storylines*. But I need to structure the narrative arcs so they build into launch and extend beyond.

June 4 is launch day. And itâ€™s coming fast.

I need a go-to-market *campaign*, not a scattershot of good ideas.

I need a **content calendar** that weaves together our strengths.

And I need to **plan for post-launch community building**, especially for when we roll out open taxonomy (sub-digs). Thatâ€™s when Jamieâ€™s community drops, and the "new Reddit" becomes more than a taglineâ€”it becomes infrastructure.

So, here's my question to myself:

**What story are we telling from now until June 4â€”and who needs to hear it first?**
---
## Therapist & Life Coach Response

First of all: wow. Youâ€™re shouldering a massive campaign with a lot of moving parts, and you're doing it while also producing and posting content almost daily. The fact that you're this deep into the strategy while also executing day-to-day social marketing? Thatâ€™s rareâ€”and exhausting. The overwhelm is real, and it's valid.

Itâ€™s clear that youâ€™re sitting on a powder keg of opportunity. But without structure, even the most promising ideas can scatter instead of spark. Right now, your job as â€œacting CMOâ€ is less about generating *more* ideas and more about **orchestrating the right sequence**.

Letâ€™s gently challenge one of your impulses: Itâ€™s tempting to â€œdo it all.â€ But if you try to run every campaign, drop every name, and target every audience all at once, you'll dilute the power of the message.

Instead, ask yourself:

- **What is the core emotional thread of this campaign?** (Nostalgia? Anti-corporate rebellion? Reclaiming the internet?)
- **What are the phases of attention you want to cultivate?** (Tease â†’ Reveal â†’ Rally â†’ Launch â†’ Sustain.)
- **What communities do you want to ignite *first*â€”and who leads them?**

If you focus on sequencing, everything changes. You donâ€™t need to build an audience from scratchâ€”you need to **activate the right people in the right order**, and tell a story that makes them feel part of a movement, not just a product launch.

---
## Relevant Author Quotes

**Casper ter Kuile, _The Power of Ritual_:**  
*"Weâ€™re not just hungry for meaning. Weâ€™re hungry for belonging."*  
â†’ Your nostalgia campaign works because people long for connection. Use this to frame DIGG as *a return to internet kinship*â€”not just a throwback, but a resurrection.

**Will Storr, _The Status Game_:**  
*"To understand people, you must understand the games theyâ€™re playing."*  
â†’ Reddit users, power mods, Apollo fansâ€”they're all playing different games. Speak directly to their *identity and frustration*. Make DIGG the next level of their game.

**Simone Stolzoff, _The Good Enough Job_:**  
*"When work becomes a religion, burnout becomes a crisis of faith."*  
â†’ Be mindful of your own energy. Youâ€™re doing the work of 4 departments. Pace yourself. Build systems that support *you*, not just the launch.

**Franklin Veaux, _More Than Two_:**  
*"There is no formula for good communication, only good principles."*  
â†’ As the platform launches, prioritize clarity and consent with your audience. Let them know whatâ€™s happening and *why* they matter in this.

**Jason Fried, _Rework_:**  
*"Start making something."*  
â†’ Donâ€™t wait until the perfect message or the perfect feature. Start shipping stories nowâ€”each one is a signal to your future users.

---
## Strategic GTM Plan (Phase-Based)

### **Phase 1: Tease (Now â€“ May 15)**
**Goal:** Build narrative anticipation without revealing the product yet.

- âœ… Digg Nation nostalgia episodes â†’ Use *behind-the-scenes snippets*, retro comparisons, and original fans.
- ğŸ“¢ Christian Selig AMA (BIG DEAL!) â†’ Make it about *what Reddit killed and what Digg is reviving*. Frame it as â€œRedemption for Apollo.â€
- ğŸ“¸ Micro-content on Twitter/Instagram from these convos. Quote cards, 30-sec clips, repost Reddit drama.

### **Phase 2: Reveal the Mission (May 15 â€“ May 29)**
**Goal:** Articulate the â€œwhy Digg, why nowâ€ message.

- ğŸ¥ CEO Justin Mazzell intro campaign â†’ 3x pieces: video, letter, Twitter thread.
- âœï¸ Long-form: â€œWhy Weâ€™re Rebuilding Diggâ€ â†’ posted on Medium + repurposed in carousel posts.
- ğŸ¤ Podcast integration: Tie Digg stories into Digg Nation episodes subtly, then overtly.

### **Phase 3: Rally the Movement (May 30 â€“ June 3)**
**Goal:** Turn attention into action. Drive signups, FOMO, exclusivity.

- ğŸ§© Invite-only beta or access code drops via Digg Nation and Twitter.
- ğŸ‘‘ Feature power users from old Digg or Reddit (Christian, Jamie teaser) with testimonials.
- ğŸ“Š Post Reddit vs. Digg comparisons as carousels, tweets, video content.

### **Phase 4: Launch Week (June 4 â€“ 11)**
**Goal:** Create a crescendo moment. Activate big voices.

- ğŸ“° PR blast (via Untold) + coordinated influencer seeding.
- ğŸ—£ï¸ Alexis Ohanian & Kevin Rose: coordinate tweetstorm, podcast, or live event.
- ğŸ‰ â€œRe-Digg the Webâ€ eventâ€”possibly live streamed or on Twitter Spaces.

### **Phase 5: Sustain & Community Build (June 11 onward)**
**Goal:** Retain attention and deepen engagement.

- ğŸ’¬ Open Taxonomy countdown.
- ğŸ  Feature â€œsub-digâ€ leaders in a seriesâ€”whoâ€™s moving over and why.
- ğŸ§  Build a "Digg Ambassador" program targeting disaffected Reddit mods and niche communities.

---
## Suggested Content Calendar (High-Level)

| Date Range        | Theme                         | Channel Focus            | Notes |
|------------------|-------------------------------|--------------------------|-------|
| Now â€“ May 15     | Nostalgia & Tease             | Podcast, Twitter, IG     | Lean into retro, Apollo story |
| May 15 â€“ May 29  | â€œWhy Digg?â€ Reveal             | Blog, Twitter, Podcast   | Start threading show + brand |
| May 30 â€“ June 3  | Call to Action: Signups, Buzz  | TikTok, Threads, Twitter | Target Gen Z, tease features |
| June 4 â€“ June 11 | LAUNCH                         | All                      | Major push, testimonials, PR |
| June 11+         | Community Migration & Build    | Podcast, Blog, Discord   | Sustain energy, open taxonomy |

---
## Social Media Topic Ideas

1. **â€œThe internet used to be weirdâ€”and we liked it.â€** (Nostalgia piece + call for a weirder web.)
2. **Apolloâ€™s Ghost: Why Reddit lost its soulâ€”and what comes next.** (Christian Selig focus)
3. **From founders to rebels: Why Kevin Rose and Alexis Ohanian are backing the rebellion.**
4. **â€œWeâ€™re not building a site. Weâ€™re building a movement.â€** (Narrative anchor post)
5. **Before algorithms ruled your feed, there was Digg. Welcome back.** (Old vs new)
6. **For the moderators who feel abandoned: You have a new home.** (Target Reddit mods)

---

Youâ€™re building something bigger than a productâ€”youâ€™re giving people a place to belong, a place to speak freely, and maybe even a little hope that the web can be joyful again. Thatâ€™s a powerful story. Now just tell it one chapter at a time.

What part of this do you want help executing firstâ€”calendar, messaging, or community onboarding?

Okay, this is real.I'm in the thick of it.Iâ€™m essentially acting as the CMO for the relaunch of **Digg** (dig.com), and while Iâ€™m surrounded by incredible assetsâ€”Digg Nation's 30K viewers, a Twitter following of 1.2 million, a killer nostalgia hook, and big-name board membersâ€”Iâ€™m also spinning in the overwhelm.Iâ€™ve got content going out daily, an all-star PR team, and a deeply loyal early audience.But thatâ€™s not enough.Right now, the primary marketing engine is the podcast, **Digg Nation**â€”but the connection between it and the Digg brand is still abstract.Itâ€™s running, itâ€™s got traction, but it hasnâ€™t fused with the product narrative yet because the product hasnâ€™t launched.Once we launch, the show and the site will be tethered.Thatâ€™s when we start threading our stories.Weâ€™re running a nostalgia campaignâ€”featuring legends like the crew from Tiki Bar TVâ€”and itâ€™s working.It's waking up the old guard.But nostalgia can only be the spark, not the fuel.I need more than eyesâ€”I need **engaged believers**.I need a community that goes beyond retro feelings and actually *wants what weâ€™re building*.Weâ€™ve got huge chess pieces to play with.Alexis Ohanian.Kevin Rose.Christian Selig (Apollo dev).Jamie from WallStreetBets.These are not minor playersâ€”they're *storylines*.But I need to structure the narrative arcs so they build into launch and extend beyond.June 4 is launch day.And itâ€™s coming fast.I need a go-to-market *campaign*, not a scattershot of good ideas.I need a **content calendar** that weaves together our strengths.And I need to **plan for post-launch community building**, especially for when we roll out open taxonomy (sub-digs).Thatâ€™s when Jamieâ€™s community drops, and the "new Reddit" becomes more than a taglineâ€”it becomes infrastructure.So, here's my question to myself:

**What story are we telling from now until June 4â€”and who needs to hear it first?**
---
## Therapist & Life Coach Response

First of all: wow.Youâ€™re shouldering a massive campaign with a lot of moving parts, and you're doing it while also producing and posting content almost daily.The fact that you're this deep into the strategy while also executing day-to-day social marketing?Thatâ€™s rareâ€”and exhausting.The overwhelm is real, and it's valid.Itâ€™s clear that youâ€™re sitting on a powder keg of opportunity.But without structure, even the most promising ideas can scatter instead of spark.Right now, your job as â€œacting CMOâ€ is less about generating *more* ideas and more about **orchestrating the right sequence**.Letâ€™s gently challenge one of your impulses: Itâ€™s tempting to â€œdo it all.â€But if you try to run every campaign, drop every name, and target every audience all at once, you'll dilute the power of the message.Instead, ask yourself:

- **What is the core emotional thread of this campaign?** (Nostalgia?Anti-corporate rebellion?Reclaiming the internet?)- **What are the phases of attention you want to cultivate?** (Tease â†’ Reveal â†’ Rally â†’ Launch â†’ Sustain.)- **What communities do you want to ignite *first*â€”and who leads them?**

If you focus on sequencing, everything changes.You donâ€™t need to build an audience from scratchâ€”you need to **activate the right people in the right order**, and tell a story that makes them feel part of a movement, not just a product launch.---
## Relevant Author Quotes

**Casper ter Kuile, _The Power of Ritual_:**  
*"Weâ€™re not just hungry for meaning.Weâ€™re hungry for belonging."*  
â†’ Your nostalgia campaign works because people long for connection.Use this to frame DIGG as *a return to internet kinship*â€”not just a throwback, but a resurrection.**Will Storr, _The Status Game_:**  
*"To understand people, you must understand the games theyâ€™re playing."*  
â†’ Reddit users, power mods, Apollo fansâ€”they're all playing different games.Speak directly to their *identity and frustration*.Make DIGG the next level of their game.**Simone Stolzoff, _The Good Enough Job_:**  
*"When work becomes a religion, burnout becomes a crisis of faith."*  
â†’ Be mindful of your own energy.Youâ€™re doing the work of 4 departments.Pace yourself.Build systems that support *you*, not just the launch.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
